p: Both concentrated hydrolates (H HD_SPE and H SD_SPE) were almost comparable in antimicrobial activity against Gram-positive S. aureus CCM 4223. The lowest inhibitory activities were observed with lavender-derived hydrolates, then laurel and fennel, and the greatest antimicrobial effect was determined with clove hydrolate, with inhibition zones up to 15.8 mm and MIC at 0.4%. In Ent. faecalis CCM 4224, an inhibition zone of 15.0 ± 0.1 mm was observed for fennel H SD_SPE. This is possibly due to the higher estragole and p-methoxy cinnamaldehyde content in H SD_SPE compared to H HD_SPE with lower antimicrobial activity. Conversely, however, fennel H HD_SPE has a higher content of eugenol and eugenyl acetate, which are known to have high antimicrobial potential [ 53]. E. coli was most suppressed by clove hydrolates (inhibition zone 13.5 ± 0.7 and 14.0 ± 0.8 mm).
